text: Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: but you really want to go for the home run. So we do not have a home run. We all know that by now. We have patients on this study where um they get the same drug you’ve got or the same dose – Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: - and their PSA drops by ninety-eight percent in the first two months. We’ve seen that. You’re not one of those guys. Patient: Okay. Doctor: We also have other people where the PSA continues to increase at the same pace or in some people it even speeds up. So you’re not in that category either. Then we have some people where the PSA you know slows down, they stay on the drug for anywhere between four to six months. It’s probably doing something, but it’s not know the desired effect or the absolute you know, perfect effect that we expected, so it’s sort of a middle ground, and yet it’s hard to justify you know to keep going if all you’re seeing is like a lukewarm type of response. Patient: Right, right, right. Doctor: So um I I think the time has come uh to uh stop this study and potentially switch gears. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um there’s two primary reasons for that. One is um PSA level has now increased by more than double - Patient: Yes. Doctor: - compared to the first one; call that the baseline number. So the trial was designed in such a way - because we don’t want to be giving people an experimental therapy and harming them by delaying improving therapy. So the trial was designed in such a way that it was built with a safety check. And the safety check is if the PSA goes up by twofold, then, in other words, a one hundred percent increase from baseline, then patient will come off study. So you have now crossed that threshold. Patient: Uh hum.

Patient: Uh hum.

text: Patient: Well I mean it’s- Doctor: It’s not always like that but it’s possible. Patient: No. No. No. It’s better to know what you’re dealing with than not. What about the treatment side of it in Europe? I mean what do they do once, let’s say you’re a candidate. Then they, do they attach to the uh to the antibody? Doctor: Well, so it’s not an antibody. Patient: Oh. Its an enzyme, enzyme.. Doctor: It’s a, uh, it’s a little very tiny little piece of just a little chemical. Patient: Oh. Doctor: That has enough specificity that it’s a glue to the antibody. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And uh so what they usually do is uh you go there. They do screening tests including an imaging test. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh they give you a treatment. At least my experience is then they keep you for a little bit and image you maybe once or twice after to look at how much your cancer took up the material.

text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? So we have um two or three uh radiation oncologists here that specialize in that type of therapy for prostate cancer patients. And the other things that are I want to discuss um with you today is a clinical trial – Patient: Okay. Doctor: - where we’re using that type of therapy but instead of not using it and not following um patients and getting data from them, we want learn something from their experience. Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: And also want to compare the outcomes of patients who get the stereotactic radiotherapy immediately versus those that are observed for a period of time and then we’ll get the stereotactic radiotherapy a little bit later. PAT; Okay. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And um the person running the trial is a baseball fan so he has the Oriole trial. Doctor: We call it the Oriole trial. And um basically I will give this consent form and you can take it home to read through. Uh um, ORIOLE basically stands for for observation versus stereotactic radiation therapy for all metastatic prostate cancer. Um, the word means few. Like . And what does metastatic prostate cancer mean a few metastases, so it means few Patient: Um, hmm. Doctor: - you are eligible for this type of therapy for this trial. Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: So in this trial, the ORIOLE part is defined as having three or fewer.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
